title: Kerning technique question
content: I’m refining kerning based on pages of words such as Kern King, printed from Indesign. Is there any reason to not make the kerning adjustments to the page, in Indesign, and then just implement the same values in Fontlab so that I don’t have to generate as many test fonts?
author: James Puckett

comments.content:
No reason not to, as long as the font is using a 1000-unit em (that’s what InDesign uses). Otherwise you’ll have to do some conversion.

T

A see a reason not to.

I mean, why do the kerning two times?

Why not just open up your words in FontLab and kern directly there? You can prepare text files and load them into Metrics window.

Then if you would like to see how it looks in InDesign, have the document ready and just update the font you are generating.

I usually generate all test-fonts directly to the Adobe\>Fonts folder for immidiate updates in InDesign. Works very handy.

Twice? Just [export](http://web.archive.org/web/20090521202625/http:/www.kltf.de/downloads/ATypI2007-CrossingBorders-kltf.pdf) kerning from the ID document, for import into the font. (That could handle UPM conversion too.)

Kerning in ID is more comfortable than kerning in the FLS Metrics panel. Just my opinion.  
But better leave the test font unhinted. Hinting may interfere with glyph positioning on the screen, which means that what you see is not what you get.
I find it easier to kern things like ligatures and contextual alts in ID, or at least to spot the obvious errors and miscalculations. I still haven’t found the best way to do that in FL.

Karsten, where do I get the plugin you show in that PDF? Is that something you sell, something you’re working on, or something dependent on that no-longer-available plugin?

As for metrics machine, well, I’m broke and unemployed.

As to the export/import scripts, I made them for my own use — they identify glyphs by GID which has awquard side-effects like: don’t apply features in ID. If I have some time later this year I’ll write a new ID script for reading out ID kerning which should also consider features applied. But maybe others have done this already? I’d appreciate it.

Indeed Metrics Machine currently looks like the best interface for manual kerning since it also helps with secondary things like producing kerning strings, creating classes and copying kerning values from glyph sets to other glyph sets (including adjusting values). I enjoyed the RoboThon presentation a lot.
I have a script (javascript) to run in Indesign. It makes an afm file from the manual kerning. This can be imported in FontLab. I will put it on my page soon.
Sign me up for that, Georg :)

I just uploaded the script to my page.

Let me know if it is working for you.

Georg
